greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of partitions of n into distinct perfect powers (including 1).
comment: Differs from the sequence A112345 which does not consider 1 as a perfect power.
link: Vaclav Kotesovec, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Perfect Power
Index entries for related partition-counting sequences
mathematica: nmax = 100; CoefficientList[Series[(1 + x) Product[(1 + Boole[GCD @@ FactorInteger[k][[All, 2]] > 1] x^k), {k, 1, nmax}], {x, 0, nmax}], x]
program: (PARI) Vec((1 + x) * prod(k=1, 100, 1 + (gcd(factorint(k)[,2])>1)*x^k) + O(x^101)) \\ _Indranil Ghosh_, Mar 21 2017
results.author: _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Mar 21 2017
